item.title: A Linux command a day (20): find -exec command
item.description: find is a very common Linux command, but we usually find more than just a look, there will be further operations, this is where exec comes into play.

item.title: A Linux command a day (19): which command
item.description: We often have to look for a file in linux, but we don’t know where it is, we can use some of the following commands to search for it.

item.title: A Linux command a day (18): whereis command
item.description: The whereis command can only be used for program name searching, and only searches binary files (argument -b), man description files (argument -m) and source files (argument -s).

item.title: A Linux command a day (17): find command
item.description: The find command under Linux searches for files in the directory structure and performs the specified operations.

item.title: A Linux command a day (16): locate command
item.description: locate allows users to quickly search for a specific file in the file system.

item.title: A Linux command a day (15): tail command
item.description: The tail command writes a file to standard output from the specified point.

item.title: A Linux command a day (14): head command
item.description: head and tail are as easy to understand as its name, it is used to display the beginning or end of a certain amount of text blocks, head is used to display the beginning of the file to the standard output, and tail is of course to see the end of the file.

item.title: A Linux command a day (13): less command
item.description: The less tool is also a tool for paging files or other output, and is supposed to be the orthodox linux tool for viewing the contents of files, which is extremely powerful.

item.title: A Linux command a day (11): nl command
item.description: The nl command is used on linux systems to calculate line numbers in files.

item.title: A Linux command a day (10): cat command
item.description: The purpose of the cat command is to concatenate files or standard input and print them.

item.title: A Linux command a day (9): touch command
item.description: The touch command in linux is not commonly used, but may be used when using make to modify the file timestamp, or to create a new file that does not exist.

item.title: A Linux command a day (8): cp command
item.description: The cp command is used to copy files or directories and is one of the most commonly used commands on Linux systems.

item.title: A Linux command a day (7): mv command
item.description: mv command is the abbreviation of move, which can be used to move files or rename files (move (rename) files), and is a common command under Linux system, often used to backup files or directories.

item.title: A Linux command a day (6): rmdir command
item.description: Today we will learn about the command in linux: rmdir command.

item.title: A Linux command a day (5): rm command
item.description: We’ve learned the command mkdir to create files and directories, and today we’ll learn the command rm to delete files and directories in linux.

item.title: A Linux command a day (4): mkdir command
item.description: The Linux mkdir command is used to create a directory with the specified name.

item.title: A Linux command a day (3): pwd command
item.description: The pwd command is used in Linux to see the full path to the current working directory.

item.title: A Linux command a day (2): cd command
item.description: 1. Command format. cd [directory name] 2. Command function. Switches the current directory to dirName

item.title: A Linux command a day (1): ls command
item.description: The Linux mkdir command is used to create a directory with the specified name.
